Stern winter no longer prevails,</br>With its raging ferocity wild;</br>The snow fills no longer the vales,</br>But the scene is all placid and mild;</br>The winds all their fury assuage,</br>The tempest's loud blast is no more,</br>No longer shall youth and old age</br>The raging of winter deplore.

'Tis spring that now visits the plain,</br>The east brightens wide with the dawn;</br>See Flora, the head of her train,</br>In the midst of the dance on the lawn.</br>All hail, thou fair emblem of love!</br>That has in the superlative state,</br>Clad in green the umbrageous grove,</br>And with gladness the earth doth elate.

The shepherds their flocks now release</br>At the rise of the lark from her nest;</br>They browse the high steep in calm peace,</br>For envy's unknown to their breast.</br>The lambs sport around the green mead,</br>To Pallas's soft flowing strains;</br>And Pan, with his musical reed,</br>Of spring the existence proclaims.

Aurora breaks forth from the skies,</br>In splendour amazingly bright;</br>The cock bids the peasants arise,</br>And to labour the rustics invite:</br>The lark from her pillow ascends,</br>Serenades the renewal of light;</br>To the sky she high towering bends,</br>And is enveloped now from sight.

The thrush hails the morning's first beam,</br>Swells her throat with the music of love;</br>And the notes of the birds near the stream,</br>Resounds from the dell through the grove.</br>All the feather'd musicians of spring,</br>The delights of the morning enjoy;</br>May they to maturity bring,</br>And no evil their broodlings annoy.

New beauties emerge from the lands,</br>The profusions of Flora behold!</br>How the tulip her colours expands,</br>And lily of white and of gold.</br>The primrose adorns the gay mead,</br>And the violet appears in the dale;</br>O'er the pasture the cowslips are spread,</br>To lavish their sweets on the gale.

The rose, royal queen of perfume,</br>Its beauteous vermilion displays;</br>And the suckle and lilac in bloom,</br>Deserve a just tribute of praise.</br>The bless'd renovation enjoy</br>In the sylvan secluded retreat;</br>For grandeur your peace will annoy—</br>Content's not in luxury's seat.

But, hark!  at the sound of the bells</br>From the hamlet that stands near the grove;</br>'Tis there the young Clerimont dwells,</br>Who's just wedded to Delia his love.</br>Ye shepherds your garlands prepare;</br>Convene all your musical powers;</br>Ye belles to the hamlet declare,</br>That mirth the most jovial is ours.</br>
